Use this assessment, the Insomnia Severity Index, to get a sense of your insomnia symptoms over time. It is recommended that you do not take this assessment more than once per week.

This graph shows how your scores on the assessment have changed over time. It is normal for your symptoms to go up and down a bit from week to week. Higher scores mean that you have more severe symptoms, so if your line is going up, you may want to check in with your provider and let him or her know (or get a provider if you don\'t already have one).
If your sleep or daytime functioning is affected by some unusual event (such as an illness, or an emergency) you may make brief notes on your diary.
If you remember your sleep habits for that day, you can edit the diary through the "Past Diaries" tab. Otherwise leave it blank.
• What do the words "bed" and "day" mean on the diary?
• Will answering these questions about my sleep keep me awake?
• What should I do if I miss a day?
• What if something unusual affects my sleep or how I feel in the daytime?
• What is a Sleep Diary?
• How often and when do I fill out the sleep diary?

It is necessary for you to complete your sleep diary every day. Remember, you will generally be answering questions about your sleep habits during the previous day and night. If possible, the sleep diary should be completed within one hour of getting out of bed in the morning.
This is not usually a problem. You should not worry about giving exact times, and you should not watch the clock. Just give your best estimate.

A sleep diary is designed to gather information about your daily sleep pattern. It should be filled out every day and is designed to be completed within two hours of getting out of bed in the morning. If you forget to fill in the diary or are unable to finish it, leave the diary blank for that day.

This diary can be used for people who are awake or asleep at unusual times. In the sleep diary, the word \‘day\' is the time when you choose or are required to be awake. The term "bed" means the place where you usually sleep.

CBT-i Coach is a mobile phone application for Veterans, Service Members, and others who are participating in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia. It is intended to augment face-to-face care with a healthcare professional. You can also use it on its own, but it is not intended to replace therapy for those who need it.\nIt will guide you through the process of learning about sleep, developing good sleep habits, and getting rid of habits that interfere with sleep. It also provides a structured program to get your biological clock reset to make it easier to go to sleep and to sleep through the night.
Reset All User Data
Provide Anonymous Usage Data

Help improve this application by automatically sending daily diagnostics and usage data. Diagnostic data may include location information. Although no one can see your personal data, looking at overall trends helps us make better products.

• Julia E. Hoffman, Psy.D.
• Katherine Taylor, M.P.H.
• Eric Kuhn, Ph.D.
• Carolyn Greene, Ph.D.
• Kenneth Weingardt, Ph.D.
• Josef I. Ruzek, Ph.D.
Subject Matter Experts
• Rachel Manber, Ph.D.\n• Mickey Trockel, M.D.\n• Philip Gehrman, Ph.D.

CBT-i Coach was a collaborative effort between VA’s National Center for PTSD, Stanford University Medical Center, and DoD’s National Center for Telehealth and Technology.\nCBT-i Coach is based on the therapy manual, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia in Veterans, by Rachel Manber, Ph.D., Leah Friedman, Ph.D., Colleen Carney, Ph.D., Jack Edinger, Ph.D., Dana Epstein, Ph.D., Patricia Haynes, Ph.D., Wilfred Pigeon, Ph.D. and Allison Siebern, Ph.D. CBT-i has been shown to be efficacious for insomnia for both Veterans and civilians.

The VA Sierra Pacific Mental Illness Research, Education, and Clinical Center is building an integrated system of clinical, research, and educational efforts designed to improve the clinical care for Veterans with dementia and with PTSD both in VISN 21 and system-wide.

Stanford School of Medicine\'s mission is to be a premier research-intensive medical school that improves health through leadership and a collaborative approach to discovery and innovation in patient care, education, and research.

The National Center for Telehealth and Technology |T2| researches, develops, evaluates, and deploys new and existing technologies for Psychological Health (PH) and Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) across the Department of Defense (DoD). 
T2 is a component center of the Defense Centers of Excellence for Psychological Health and Traumatic Brain Injury (DCoE).

	"Technology to Make People Healthy"

For more information about insomnia and other topics for Veterans, see http://ptsd.va.gov.

The National Center for PTSD, within the Department of Veterans Affairs, aims to help U.S. Veterans and others through research, education, and training on trauma and PTSD.\n\"Advancing Science and Promoting Understanding of Traumatic Stress\"
Read about how your sleep functioning, sleep environment and daily habits can affect your health. Find definitions for terms used in cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia.
CBT-i Glossary
Healthy Sleep Habits
Sleep 101

CBT-i - Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia - is a non-medication treatment of insomnia that is based on scientific knowledge about sleep. The goals of CBT-i are to help you fall asleep, stay asleep, and improve your daytime functioning as a result of better sleep at night. 

	• The "cognitive" part of CBT-i focuses on thoughts, feelings, and expectations about sleep and insomnia that may stand in the way of good sleep. 
	• The "behavioral" aspect of CBT-i helps people adopt personal sleep habits that, based on the science of sleep, will help them sleep better.
What is CBT-i?
Why Do We Sleep?

Sleep, like oxygen, food and water, is one of our basic daily needs. Sleep scientists disagree on the fundamental biological purpose of sleep. Some believe that during sleep the human body restores and repairs cells and tissues that have been damaged while we are awake. Other experts believe that sleep is essential to the maintenance of normal human metabolism. There is also evidence that sleep is important for storing memories. Despite these differences, sleep experts generally agree that to function best we all require consistent, good quality sleep.

Many research studies have shown that sleep is a process made up of two states: Rapid Eye Movement (REM sleep) and Non-Rapid Eye Movement (non REM) sleep. Non REM sleep is composed of several stages, and occupies about 75- 80% of the night\'s sleep of a \"typical\" young, healthy adult. The rest of the night\’s sleep is REM sleep.
The Stages of Sleep

N1: People experience stage N1 sleep as very light; when awakened, many individuals think they have not been asleep. Nonetheless, stage N1 seems to be an essential part of normal sleep. People with insomnia and older adults spend more of their night\’s sleep in stage N1 than those without insomnia.
N2: N2 occupies about 40-55% of the night\'s sleep in a young adult. It is harder to wake a person from this stage and most people know they have been asleep.

N3: Brain activity during N3 sleep is also called slow-wave sleep because it is characterized by slow, distinctive waves called Delta waves. N3 is perceived as the deepest sleep; it is hardest to wake people up from this stage. People tend to have more stage N3 sleep on nights following prolonged wakefulness.

REM: REM sleep is when most dreaming occurs. During REM sleep, bursts of rapid eye movements can be observed and heart and breathing rates become less regular. There is increased blood flow to the brain. Interestingly, brain wave activities during REM sleep are a bit similar to those seen during wakefulness. However, during REM sleep the body\'s skeletal muscles are in a state of relative paralysis which prevents people from \'acting out\' their dreams

Sleep Drive: Our sleep drive is lowest in the morning and gradually increases as the day progresses. Sleeping gradually reduces our sleep drive as we "recharge our energy reserve", which is why napping close to bedtime (for example, dozing off while watching TV in the evening) can make it harder for us to fall asleep later. The longer the time that has elapsed since we last slept, the stronger is the sleep drive and the easier it will be to fall asleep. When the sleep drive is very strong we feel sleepy.

Circadian Process: People have powerful internal \‘clocks\’ that affect their bodily functioning, including digestion, body temperature, and sleep/wake pattern. Most of these \'clocks\' seem to work across roughly 24-hour periods. Irregular sleep schedules weaken our biological clocks, which is why it is particularly important to keep regular wake and out of bed times. Our clocks use light signals to reset, so getting out of bed at the same time each day keeps the clock ticking with a strong and regular beat, which supports good sleep.

Arousal: Feeling \"on guard\" or anxious can mask sleepiness (strong sleep drive) and make sleep difficult. For example, when a sleep-deprived person is anxious about having to appear before a traffic judge, this person generally does not feel sleepy at the hearing despite not getting enough sleep the night before. When the court appearance is over, and the person is relaxed, he may nod off while reading a magazine article because his strong sleep drive is no longer masked by anxiety. This example demonstrates how the balance of sleep drive and arousal (such as a perceived threat, anxiety, active mind, or body tension) determines the likelihood of sleep at a given time. Common sources of arousal at bedtime include thinking about issues that have not been adequately resolved or addressed during the day, worrying about sleep, trying to remember what needs to be done the next day, and worrying about things not in one\’s control.
There are two processes that regulate sleep and wakefulness, the sleep drive and the circadian process. Arousal also affects our ability to sleep.
Sleep Regulators
Sleepiness vs. Tiredness

Often people use the terms \"sleepy\" and \"tired\" interchangeably, but they actually mean different things. \"Tired\" can mean that the person has low energy, but not necessarily a need to sleep. \"Sleepy\" generally refers to an actual need for sleep. Thinking about your levels of feeling tired and sleepy separately might help you determine when you have an actual need for sleep (strong sleep drive), rather than an overall lack of energy. This can help you decide when to actually try to sleep and when to rest your body.

Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) describes a group of symptoms that occur in response to a traumatic event such as being involved in an automobile accident or military combat. These symptoms include feeling tense or \"on guard\" much of the time, having flashbacks or nightmares and feeling disconnected from people and situations. Trouble sleeping is an extremely common symptom of PTSD.\n\nSome individuals report avoiding sleeping because they are afraid they might have nightmares, or they may not be able to respond to urgent situations that might arise. They might engage in \"safety behaviors\", such as listening for noises outside or checking locks on doors and windows. People with PTSD may prefer sleeping in locations other than the bedroom or try to delay bedtime. Sleep can also be hard if it brings back memories of trauma, for example, if the trauma happened at night.
PTSD and Sleep
Depression and Sleep
Nightmares
Sleep Apnea

Most people with depression have trouble sleeping. Some wake up earlier than desired or planned and others may find it difficult to get out of bed because they do not derive much pleasure from what they do during the day. The good news is that CBT-i is effective even for people who experience depression. Improved sleep can improve mood

Because sleep deprivation can cause confusion when awakened suddenly, it is dangerous to keep weapons within easy access. Being confused and frightened upon waking will increase the likelihood of misjudging the situation and unintentionally discharging a loaded weapon. Therefore, it’s important to lock up or unload weapons at home even if doing so increases the sense of vulnerability and anxiety, which can lead to sleeplessness in the short run.

Nightmares are bad dreams that cause awakening and strong negative emotional responses like fear upon waking up from the dream. For veterans, many nightmares relate to dangerous combat activities. Awakening after a nightmare can result in people replaying the nightmare, trying to figure out why the nightmare happened and what it might mean. Some experts believe that by avoiding sleeping and replaying nightmares people may be more likely to have future nightmares.
Weapons and Sleep

Sleep apnea is a sleep disorder in which the airway passages (nose or throat) are fully or partially obstructed. These events can lead to a decrease in oxygen levels in the blood and awakenings. Nighttime symptoms of sleep apnea include loud snoring, snorting, and gasping for air. Unless told by a partner, many people have no idea they have these symptoms of sleep apnea. Daytime symptoms of sleep apnea include feeling tired in the morning and sleepy during the day. Other daytime symptoms include a morning headache that resolves shortly after rising and waking with a dry mouth. If you experience these symptoms on a regular basis you should talk to your doctor. Sleep apnea increases the risk of heart disease and stroke.

Certain medications and commonly used substances can disrupt sleep. These include some asthma medications (e.g. theophylline), some over the counter decongestants and allergy and cold medicines, some steroids (e.g., prednisone), beta blockers (medicines used to treat heart conditions), medications for ADHD (e.g., Adderall) and some antidepressants (e.g., Wellbutrin). Ask your physician if any medications you are taking might interfere with sleep. Don\’t stop taking prescribed medications without first checking with your doctor.\n\nWhile \"sleeping pills\" are useful when taken for a short time , prolonged, chronic use can cause tolerance (needing more medication to get the same effect) and psychological dependence. Each person has a different level of tolerance for these medications and will have a different reaction to their use. Some experience the effect of the medication for a long time and are sleepy or lethargic the next day. Make sure to only use sleep medications as instructed by your physician and to report any side effects to your treatment team.
Medications

Preoccupation with small and big worries, mulling over your problems, or planning future events while in bed can keep you awake. When disruptive thinking occurs frequently, you may find it helpful to set aside a time each day to do the thinking, worrying, problem-solving, and planning you need to do. Then, if intrusive thoughts occur during your sleep period, postpone them to the \"thinking and worrying time\" during the next day. By scheduling a daily time to focus on your concerns you will find that you are having fewer worried thoughts while you are in bed. For help with his, see \"Scheduling a Worry Time\" in the \"Tools\" tab.\n\n Many people find themselves worrying about not sleeping, which, unfortunately, can also keep them awake. Remember that, while not sleeping can be uncomfortable, your body is designed to tolerate less-than-perfect sleep some nights. In fact, losing sleep can increase your sleep drive, which may result in improved sleep the following nights. It’s important to reduce night time anxiety in order to improve your chances of getting quality sleep.
Worrying in Bed

You can create a \"buffer zone\" for yourself, which is a quiet time right before bedtime that allows you to wind down. It provides a transition between activities of the day and the quiet, more peaceful time of sleep. Shedding the day’s excitements and tensions will calm you and allow sleep to unfold naturally. For ideas about ways to create a buffer zone, see the \"Tools\" tab.
Being aware of the time can increase frustration and interfere with sleep. Put your clock across the room, turn it around, and do not check the time in the middle of the night.

Sleeping at times other than your specified time in bed can weaken your sleep drive and could throw off the natural circadian rhythm of your body. However, if you find yourself feeling very sleepy (not just tired, but actually sleepy) you can take a brief (15 to 30 minutes) nap. Sleepy people make mistakes, misjudge situations, and may accidently hurt themselves or others. Therefore, do not try and stay awake just to keep in line with your sleep prescription. Safety supersedes all other sleep guidelines.\n\n If you feel like you have to nap, try to do it 7 to 9 hours after your morning wake up time, which for most people is in the mid-afternoon. The nap will then coincide with the pattern of your biological clock, which has a natural dip (lower alertness) at that time. Ideally naps should be taken at approximately the same time every day, otherwise they may weaken your sleep signal. Naps should be taken in your bed because you are training yourself to associate the bed with sleep. Set your alarm so you don\’t nap too long.
Watching the Clock
Napping
Winding Down

Nicotine leaves the body fairly quickly, usually about two hours after use. This can create cravings in the middle of the night. For this reason it is best to avoid smoking at least two hours before bedtime, if possible.

Your sleep environment needs to be quiet, dark, and safe with a comfortable temperature. Noise and light (even dim light) may interrupt or shorten your sleep. One good way to filter out unwanted noise is to sleep with \"white noise\" in the background. This can be the sound of a fan, the hum of static on the radio, or you can purchase a \"white noise\" machine to help with sleep.
Nicotine Use
Using the Bedroom for Two Activities Only
Eating
Getting Comfortable
Caffeine Use

Exercise too close to bedtime may have a negative impact on sleep. Exercise activates the body, and raises the core body temperature, which doesn’t allow the body to experience its normal drop in temperature prior to sleep. Strenuous exercise should be avoided about four hours before bedtime. Gentle stretching exercises before bedtime are OK and may even be relaxing.

Alcoholic beverages can be relaxing and make people feel drowsy, however they can have the opposite effect later in the night. As alcohol is metabolized, it leads to restless and disturbed sleep. For most people with no history of alcoholism, one glass of wine or beer with dinner scheduled 3-4 hours before bedtime is not likely to have a negative impact on sleep. However, for some very sensitive individuals complete elimination of alcohol in the evening may be advisable.

The process of falling asleep slows down the digestive system. A heavy meal close to bedtime may therefore lead to indigestion or reflux during the night, both of which disturb sleep. Allowing a 4 hour window between eating and sleeping to let food to digest is a good sleep practice. However if you are hungry, a light snack is appropriate.

Caffeine is a relatively long-acting stimulant whose effects may last for several hours after it is consumed. People differ greatly in how caffeine affects them and in the length of time it lasts, for example, older adults tend to be more sensitive to caffeine. Caffeine can remain active 4-5 hours after it is consumed, so try to avoid having caffeine after lunch if you want to make sure it doesn’t affect your sleep. Limit consumption of caffeinated beverages to the equivalent of no more than three, eight- ounce cups daily. To set goals for caffeine use, check out the \"Tools\" tab.

While in bed, you should avoid doing things that you do when you are awake. Do not read, watch TV, eat, study or use your phone or laptop. Doing these things in bed creates associations between the bed and activities other than sleep, which can train your mind to stay awake while in bed. By only using your bed for sleep, you can help it become a place where sleep comes naturally. Sexual activity is the only exception to this guideline.\n\nThe most important activity that you should eliminate from the bed is the activity of \"trying to sleep\" because it inevitably interferes with the natural sleep process. If you find yourself thinking about sleep while in bed, get up. It can be hard not to use your bed for other things, especially if you live in a studio apartment or a dorm room, but it can be an important part of improving your sleep habits.

Sleep Efficiency
Total Sleep Time
Feeling an overall lack of energy or general fatigue.
Bed, in the context of this app, means any place designated for sleep.
Feeling a need for sleep (compare to a feeling of "tiredness").
Total Sleep Time: The actual amount of sleep you get during a sleep period. It’s equal to total sleep period minus awake time.
Time in Bed is the amount of recommended time to be in bed. It is determined by taking the recommended awake time minus bed time.

Going to bed and waking up at the same times each day can help strengthen the natural cues from your internal biological sleep clock. This is part of the reason sleep therapists recommend a sleep prescription, a set bedtime and set wake time, for people who are having sleep difficulties

Your sleep efficiency is the proportion of the time you spend asleep relative to the time you spend in bed. For example, if you sleep for 4 hours out of the 6 hours you are in bed, your sleep efficiency is 4/6 or 66.6%. The formula is for sleep efficiency is: average sleep efficiency = average total sleep time / average time in bed

A sleep diary is designed to gather information about your daily sleep pattern. It should be filled out every day and is designed to be completed within two hours of getting out of bed in the morning. If you forget to fill in the diary or are unable to finish it, leave the diary blank for that day.

This section provides interactive modules that can help you develop and maintain helpful sleep habits and relax and ready your body for sleep. You can also use this section to learn about how to continue to have positive sleep habits in the future.

Using CBT-i guidelines can help create a schedule and environment that helps you sleep. Use this \"Build New Sleep Habits\" section to implement some changes in your routine. If you are looking for ways to quiet your mind, try some of the activities under the \"Quiet Your Mind\" tab.

Staying awake until you are truly sleepy can help strengthen your sleep drive and encourage sleep to come more easily. Don\’t know the difference between sleepy and tired? Check out the \"Learn\" tab .Use these activities to help you stay up until your prescribed bedtime. If you are not sleepy at your prescribed bedtime, look at the \"Quiet Your Mind\" section for ways to help your mind and body relax. Remember never to stay up when sleepy if it could interfere with activities or responsibilities where sleepiness can be dangerous
Set Up Your Sleep Environment
Go to Bed Only When Sleepy
Get Out of Bed When You Can\'t Sleep
Get Out of Bed at Your Prescribed Time
Set Caffeine Goals
Incorporating new habits into your nighttime routine can help sleep come more easily. Use the following tools to shape your current schedule into one that leads to quality sleep.

It is important to manage caffeine intake if you are having trouble sleeping. People who are having difficulty sleeping should drink no more than three 8-oz cups of caffeinated beverages per day, and avoid having any after lunch. If you would like to manage your caffeine intake, set a daily goal below:
Reducing Caffeine
New Sleep Habits
Daily Caffeine Drink Limit
Use the following checklist to make sure you have the optimum sleep environment. If it is not possible to adapt your environment to these guidelines, read about alternate possibilities.
Low Noise Level
Room is dark
Keeping a home environment that is consistent with good sleep habits is a key part of improving your sleep. Use the suggested adaptations when changing your environment is difficult.
Temperature is comfortable
Sleep is undisturbed by others
Reserve my bed for sleep/sex
Noise from traffic or the outside environment can be difficult to control. If noise may be keeping you awake consider using a fan or white noise machine to make your bed area more conducive to sleep.
Sometimes morning light, the full moon, or street lighting can interfere with getting a good night’s sleep. Consider changing window coverings if light may be an issue.
Feeling too warm or cold during the night can interfere with sleep. Consider layering sleep clothing and blankets so temperature is easier to adjust, or purchase a fan or space heater.
Consider alternate sleep arrangements with partners and pets that will allow you the space and quiet you need.

If living in a dorm or studio makes reserving your bed for sleep and sex difficult, create another corner in your room for other activities. If you must use the bed for other activities try covering the bed with a day blanket (of a different color than your night blanket). When you are ready for sleep, remove the blanket. This will help cue your mind to associate your bed with sleep.
Sleep Environment

If you are having trouble staying awake until your scheduled bedtime, see the Activities to Keep You Awake, below, for ideas on how to keep yourself up until it’s time for bed. If an activity continues to work for you tap the star next to it to highlight it.
Call a friend
Do stretching exercises
Watch a mystery show
Write a long letter
Work on a project or hobby that you find interesting
Read a book that is hard to put down
Stand up and walk around
Do house chores
Listen to upbeat music (sing or hum along)
Watch a comedy show
Dance to upbeat music
Watch a comedy show
Stand up and walk around
Go outside (if it safe)
Turn on all the lights
Prepare meals for the rest of the week
Pack tomorrow’s lunch
Sort laundry
Organize computer files
Organize drawers/shelves
Activities To Keep You Awake
Go to Bed
Get out of Bed

Getting out of bed when you are having trouble sleeping helps prevent your mind from associating being awake with being in bed, which can help your sleep in the future. Use some of the activity ideas to keep yourself relaxed and occupied until you are very sleepy and ready to return to bed. When you get out of bed you should do things that are engaging but calming.

Getting out of bed in the morning at your prescribed time helps keep your sleep schedule consistent and prevents you from associating being in bed with being awake. Use these ideas for activities to help motivate you to start your day. Also consider setting an activity reminder that coincides with your prescribed wake up time.
Activities for the Middle of the Night
Play solitaire online or with cards at home, as long as you are not too competitive about it
Sort out junk mail and bills (but don’t pay bills)
Update your address books or start one online or on paper
Look through catalogs
De-clutter your coffee table, dining room table, kitchen countertops or desk
Create a detailed menu for dinners
Make a grocery shopping list for the week
Catch up on your reading (as long as the reading materials can keep you awake)
Create a list of activities that you\’d enjoy doing on weekends and vacations
Read your kids\’ books- these are often very comforting and positive in their messages
Make a materials list for a project around the house
Choose one or two drawers to clean out (in your desk, kitchen, bathroom)
Shop for holiday, wedding or birthday gifts online
Read magazines or other light material
Jot down thoughts on a notepad for an assigned period of time. Use this exercise to help decrease nighttime thinking and worrying
Knit or do other crafts that you can stop working on when you feel sleepy
Watch infomercials, C-SPAN, The Weather Channel, or other repetitive television shows
Organize collections of CDs or DVDs and choose some to donate or sell if you no longer enjoy them
Work on photo albums or scrapbooks
Fold clothes, put away clothes
Morning Activities
Get Out of Bed at Your Prescribed Time

Having an activity to look forward to in the morning can help getting out of bed at the same time each day seem more doable. See Morning Activities, below, for ideas for things to do in the morning. If an activity continues to work for you, you may want to tap the star next to it to highlight it.
Watch the sunrise
Take the dog for a walk
Meditate or Pray
Go to the grocery store or other stores that open early
Make lunch for yourself and for everyone else in the house
Read the newspaper or read the news online
Go to your gym or workout at home
Enjoy being able to get ready for work and kids ready for school without having to rush
Sort out some kids’ toys and choose things for Goodwill or a yard sale
Sort and start your laundry, or iron clothes for work
Start a budget for your family on a spreadsheet or in a notebook
Send emails to friends or check your work email
Shred or erase old computer disks, DVDs, etc.
Organize all of your bills, receipts, coupons and warranty information in a filing cabinet or folders
Get some of the preparation started for dinner dishes (marinating, chopping vegetables, and so on)
Make the bed and tidy up your bedroom
Open the curtains and blinds in the house
Sweep your sidewalk or steps, or shovel snow
Do some light gardening or water houseplants or those around your porch
Review your to-do list for the day or the week

Relaxation is an integral part of being able to sleep. Use the tools in this section to encourage relaxation of the mind and body, so that sleep comes naturally.

Having a wind-down time before you go to sleep can help relax your mind and body. See the Evening Activities below to explore some ideas for things to do during your buffer zone. If an activity continues to work for you, you may want to tap the star next to it to mark it as a favorite.
Evening Activities
Knit
Floss
Listen to slow, relaxing or instrumental music
Organize collections - photos, old letters, books, or other items
Gather old bills and statements and shred them
Polish your shoes
Catch up on laundry or folding clothes
Write in your journal
Iron or mend clothing
Give yourself a pedicure, manicure, or facial
Do some stretches to relax your muscles
Sweep or mop the kitchen floor while no one else is there to walk on it
Take the dog for a long walk
Groom your pets
Surf the internet (non-stressful topics only) or do research for major purchases (cars, appliances, vacations)
Watch movies or episodes of television shows that you haven\’t seen in a long time (no action films or thrillers)
Take a bath or long shower
Make your lunch for the next day
Prepare dinner for the next day and store it in the refrigerator
Choose clothes to wear the next day
Write thank you notes or short emails to friends
I will survive even if I don\'t sleep at all tonight.
I\'ve done this before, so I know I can do it again.
I don\'t have to feel comfortable all the time. I am human.
This is another challenge that I will figure out and face.
I have been through this before and been just fine.
One night of poor sleep is not the end of the world.
This tossing and turning at night will pass.

Although it feels like I will never get a good night’s sleep it may not be the case. Anticipating that I may not sleep well will likely make my sleep worse. I have functioned well before even after not sleeping well.
I have functioned poorly before even after I did sleep well
Although I am anticipating a poor night\'s sleep, it could be fine…I have slept well before.
The body naturally regulates sleep; even if I miss some sleep I will be able to function.
If I do not worry about sleep, having poor sleep one night will likely improve my sleep the next night.
I have been through many hard things in my life and survived.
Nightmares are disturbing, but they\'re not real. I am safe.
I know I\'m in a safe place, even though my mind is telling me something else.

Changing the way you think can change the way you feel and how well you sleep. Concentrate on alternative thoughts to begin to feel better.
Worried About Sleep
Worried About Trauma
Perspective

The Change Your Perspective tool provides reminders that can help give you hope and confidence. We all have a constant stream of thoughts running through our minds—this is called self-talk. Negative self-talk, like believing that things are terrible or that the worst is about to happen can stress your body and keep you on alert all the time. These positive self-talk reminders give you something you can hold on to; they can help you think more realistically, and may even help you manage situations more effectively.
Working some wind-down time into your sleep routine can help sleep come more easily. View the activity suggestions for ways to engage in calming activities that help prepare you for sleep.

Scheduling a worry time can help people gain some control over anxious thoughts that may be keeping them awake. Pick a daily time at which you can review the thoughts that may prevent you from falling asleep. Try not to pick a time too close to your bedtime, so that you have an opportunity to wind down afterwards.

One strategy that has been shown to be helpful for quieting anxious thoughts is scheduling a worry time. Although this may seem like the opposite of a useful goal for people struggling with anxiety, it actually can help get control over rumination. If you find yourself up at night worrying, try entering a scheduled day and time below that you can think about the issues that are on your mind.

For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed. This mindfulness exercise will help you practice mindfulness of physical sensations. Practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Practice these mindfulness exercises with audio guidance, or on your own. Please do not do these exercises while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.

Practice being mindful of your full range of sensations, thoughts, and experiences in the moment. Practice these mindfulness exercises with audio guidance, or on your own. Please do not do these exercises while driving or doing other work that requires your full attention.

Please read the following script through until you feel familiar with it, then follow the instructions on your own.

Start this exercise by finding a comfortable position sitting or lying down. Take a few deep breaths—relax.

Imagine that you\’re looking up into the bright blue sky. Feel the sensation of the air - maybe a light wind passing by - and you can feel that air move across your skin. Notice that there are large white puffy clouds that move from one side of the sky to the other. Follow the large white clouds as they appear on one edge of your vision, move across the sky and then pass out of your vision on the other side. And after one cloud make its movement across the sky then another cloud comes and does the same. And they keep coming, one after another, moving across the sky.

Begin becoming aware of the thoughts that are going through your mind. Take whatever the first thought is that comes to your mind and see if you can take that thought and place it on one of the clouds and just let the cloud flow by. Then do the same thing with the next thought that comes to your mind. You can also put sensations, feelings, or urges on clouds and let them flow by. You might choose to represent those thoughts or experiences as one word that you put on the cloud or it might be an image or some other way of representing whatever it is that you are experiencing. There is no right or wrong way to do it. Simply practice noticing whatever is there for you, in turn placing each one on a cloud and letting it move past.

If you get distracted or think that you can’t do this, put that thought on a cloud, watch it go by, and return to the process. You might even have to do that over and over again.

Notice one last thought or experience, place it on a cloud and let the cloud trail by while you bring your awareness back here to this moment. Notice any sensations in your body. Notice the sensation of breathing. Take two more deep breaths and whenever you are ready you can open your eyes and return your awareness to your surroundings.

Please read the following script through until you feel familiar with it, then follow the instructions on your own.

Start this exercise by finding a comfortable position sitting or lying down. Take a few deep breaths—relax.

Now bring your awareness to your fingers. Rub them together and notice their texture, temperature, and the sensations as they move. Can you feel the indentations of your fingerprints? Take your time noticing all of this. Now rest your fingers where they were before. What are they touching? What does that feel like? Is it soft? hard? What are its features and textures? Really notice what you feel.

Now bring attention to your hands and arms. What do they feel like? Relaxed? Heavy? Tense? Painful? Try to observe these sensations, including uncomfortable ones, without judgment. 

Notice your toes now. Wiggle them and feel whatever is around and under them. How does it feel? Can you tell what it is just by feeling?

Next, notice how your head is positioned. Is it upright? drooping? Is your neck turned in a particular direction? Simply notice this without trying to change it. Also note the sensations in your head and neck, including temperature, pain, and relaxation. Take your time noticing. What about your face? Is your brow smooth or wrinkled up? How does it feel? Now notice your nose. Can you breathe freely? As you breathe, notice the sensations in your nose and lungs—expansion, tickling, warmth, or coolness. Then notice how your mouth is positioned? Is it pursed? Open? Closed? Is the inside of your mouth wet or dry? Just notice. Also, notice how your skin feels. Is it dry? Itchy, tingling, hot or cool? Is there no sensation?

Now notice your chest and belly. Place one hand on your chest and one on your belly. Can you feel your body breathing? What is that like? Are you breathing fast or slow? Is your breath going more into your belly or your chest? Just notice all these sensations.

Next expand your attention to include your whole body. Where are you sitting or lying? Can you feel the back side of your body touching the chair or bed in places? Without moving, just observe your body’s position.

When you are ready, look around the room and notice your surroundings, without judgment. When you are ready, stop this exercise and continue to relax.

Difficulty sleeping can return in certain situations; this is normal.

If you find that your sleep is getting worse take the self-quiz below to see what areas you might be able to improve:

Which of these have you had trouble with?
I have trouble waking up and getting out of bed at my prescribed wake time.
I have trouble going to bed only when I\'m sleepy and not before my prescribed bedtime.
It is hard for me to get out of bed when I can\’t sleep.
I have trouble creating a buffer zone to wind down before sleep.
I worry in bed.
I am having trouble limiting my caffeine use.
I don\’t have a sleep environment that is quiet, dark and cool.
I can\'t relax enough for sleep

Sleep is the result of a complex physiological system that is very sensitive to distress. This means that difficulty sleeping can return in certain situations. Use this tool to pinpoint ways to maintain good sleep when symptoms of insomnia return.

Based on these issues, try looking at the following tools:

When to Seek Help

If you notice new sleep-related problems, contact your doctor and schedule an appointment. Such problems can include:

• Loud snoring

• Stopping breathing, breathing pauses, gasping or snorting during sleep

• Falling asleep unintentionally or dozing during the day

• A creep-crawling sensation in your lower legs in the evening, along with an irresistible urge to move your legs to get rid of the feeling

• Very frequent leg jerking during your sleep

• Any other unusual new sleep experiences
Here are the items that might create problems for you:
Get Out of Bed at Your Prescribed Time
Go to Bed Only When Sleepy
Get Out of Bed When You Can\'t Sleep
Winding Down
Schedule Worry Time
Setting Caffeine Goals
Set Up Your Sleep Environment

This exercise will guide you in imaging a pleasant scene in order to reduce stress and help you relax. With this guided imagery you can relax your muscles and breathe more deeply while you focus on the relaxing scene in order to relax more deeply.
Forest Imagery
Road Imagery
Beach Imagery

You are about to be led through a relaxation exercise focused on visualizing something pleasant. This exercise takes about 4 minutes. It has accompanying audio, so you will have to find a quiet place or put on your headphones now.
First, remove all distractions - let others know not to bother you.
Make yourself comfortable, so that your thoughts are on the image and nothing else.
Sit, or lie down, in a quiet, comfortable place.
Mentally scan your body for tense muscles.
If you find a muscle is tense, or clenched, relax it.
During the imagery exercise, involve all of your senses in the image: sight, sound, smell, touch, and taste.
Get completely focused.
The more focused you are, the better.
Close your eyes, or lower your gaze.
Imagine that you are walking down a path, into a lush forest.
As you walk along the path, you completely take in the sights, sounds, smells, and feel of the place.
All around you are trees, grasses, mossy ground cover, and fragrant flowers.
You hear the soothing sounds of birds chirping, and the wind as it gently blows through the treetops.
You smell the rich dampness of the forest floor, the smells of moist vegetation and new growth.
Through gaps in the treetops, you see the sun high in the cloudless blue sky.
The sun is dispersed through the canopy of the treetops and filters down onto the forest floor, creating intricate patterns of light and shadow.
With each breath you take in this place, you feel a deep sense of peace and relaxation.
You soon come to a clearing.
There are several flat rocks in the clearing surrounded by a soft moss.
A small stream runs along the rocks.
You lie back on one of the rocks, or on the cushiony moss, and put your feet into the cool water.
You feel the warm sun and a gentle, light breeze through your hair and across your skin.
The sparkling clear water rushes around the multi-colored rocks, making little whirlpools and eddies.
You put your hand into the water and lift a handful to your lips.
The water is cool and refreshing.
You close your eyes and listen to the water trickling around the rocks. You bathe in the warm sun, and feel as though you\'re floating, relaxing deeper and deeper.
You let yourself sink further into relaxation while continuing to be aware of the sights, smells, sounds, and feel of the forest around you.
You allow yourself to let go of any concerns or worries, and to feel completely refreshed and rejuvenated in this place.
When you\'re ready, imagine that you slowly get up and leave the clearing.
As you walk back down the path through the forest, fully take in this place, and realize that you may return whenever you wish by the same path.
Each time you enter this place, you will feel relaxed and at peace.

Your bare feet feel the rough, weathered step

This activity will guide you through a brief exercise in which you take slower, depper breaths to help you relax. Taking slow, deep breaths helps you balance the carbon dioxide and orygen in your blood. This calms your nervous system, creating a \"relaxation response.\" Deep breathing exercises can help manage stress and insomnia, focus the mind and improve health.
Listen to the audio and follow along with the exercise.

You are about to be led through a progressive muscle relaxation exercise. You will progress through each of your major muscle groups, tensing and relaxing as you go. This exercise takes about 9 minutes. It has audio, so you will need to find a quiet place or put on your headphones now. Sit down in a comfortable chair or lay down. Do not do this exercise while driving.

This exercise will guide you, either sitting comfortably or lying down, through tensing and relaxing a sequence of muscle groups. This allows muscles to relax more deeply than usual. This exercise can help decrease heart rate and blood pressure, slow breathing, decrease muscle tension and clear thinking\n\nThis exercise is also great because over time you can train yourself to really know what tense muscles feel like. The, when you recognize that your muscles are tense or becoming tense you can immediately switch your muscles to the more relaxed state because you have trained yourself to know how relaxed muscles feel
Please note that if you have injuries such as back pain or a knee injury, you should avoid tensing muscles that might affect that injury.
To begin, close your eyes and take a deep breath into your belly.
Then exhale with a sigh.
Again, take a deep breath, and imagine clean air going down your throat, and filling your lungs, and then exhale with a sigh.
Take another deep breath, and as you release it, think the word \"Relax\", silently to yourself.
Allow your breath to be smooth and rhythmic, inhaling and exhaling at a pace that is comfortable for you.
As you continue to breathe, continue to say the word \"Relax\" to yourself, slowly and calmly, each time you breathe out.
As you do this, imagine that the tension throughout your body begins to melt away.
To begin, clench both your fists, and bend your elbows, drawing your forearms and hands up towards your shoulders, tightening your biceps to do so.
Hold the muscles in your hands and arms tight, and notice the sensations of pulling, discomfort, and tightness.
Hold the tension, while you take a deep breath into your belly, and then slowly exhale, as you release the muscles of your hands and arms.
Let your hands and fingers relax completely, and let your arms become limp at your side or in your lap.
Feel the sensation of relaxation, as the tension drains away from your arms and hands, and allow the muscles to become looser and looser.
You may notice that they feel lighter and warmer.
Breathing in slowly, and out, thinking the word \"Relax\" each time you breathe out.
Now bring your attention to your face, and tighten your forehead, the muscles around your eyes and your jaw, by squeezing your eyes tight, clenching your jaw, and wrinkling your forehead and nose
Feel the wrinkling and pulling sensations across the forehead and the top of your head.
Feel the tightness around your eyes and cheeks, and the tension in your jaw.
Hold that tension, and take a deep breath into your belly, and then slowly exhale, as you let your face relax completely.
Feel the muscles in your forehead becoming smooth and limp, the muscles of your cheeks and eyes softening, and your jaw relaxing. Let your lips part slightly, and let your jaw hang loose.
Notice the tension melting away. Feel your muscles becoming softer, more relaxed, and feel the warmth and lightness that replaces the tension that was there before.
Continue to breathe slowly and gently, thinking the word \"Relax\" each time you exhale.
Tighten your shoulders by raising them up as if you were going to touch them to your ears, tensing without straining.

Feel the tension in your shoulders radiating down into your back and up into your neck and the top of your back. Hold that. Notice those sensations and take a deep breath into your belly, and then slowly exhale as you relax your shoulders.
Let your shoulders droop down and let your neck relax completely, feeling very relaxed
Notice the contrast between the tightness you felt and the relaxation you feel now.
Let your head relax, as if there\'s nothing holding it except the support behind it. Feel the sense of relaxation around your neck and shoulders as you let the tension drain away
Continue to breathe slowly and deeply.
Now bring your attention to your stomach.
Tighten the muscles of your stomach by pulling your belly in towards your spine tightly.
Hold that pose.
Feel the sensation of the tension. Hold it while you are taking a deep breath, and then slowly exhale as you relax your muscles.
Imagine a wave of relaxation spreading through your belly. Allow the muscles of your stomach to be soft and relaxed, letting go more and more.

Notice the difference between the tension you felt and the relaxation you feel now. Let any remaining tension melt away, continuing to breathe gently in and out, feeling yourself become calmer and more relaxed.

Now tighten your buttocks by squeezing them together, and at the same time squeeze the muscles of your thighs. You can lift your feet up to help tense your leg muscles. Notice the sensations of pulling, tightness, and constriction.
Hold on to that tension, and focus on it, and take a deep breath. Then slowly exhale as you relax your buttocks and thighs.
Allow your muscles to relax completely, and to let any tension drain away, melting away.
Feel how the muscles of your hips and legs feel different now than when they did when you were clenching them.
Really notice the difference. Continue to let go further and further, experiencing an even deeper relaxation, breathing in and out, slowly and gently, in and out.
Now tighten the muscles of your calves and your feet as you flex your feet, pulling your toes towards you.
Flex these muscles carefully to avoid a cramp.
Continue to flex your feet, feeling the muscles of your calves, feet, and toes tighten and pull. Hold the tension for another second and take a deep breath. And now, slowly, exhale, release.

As your muscles relax, notice how the sensations in your calves and feet change, perhaps feeling softer, or warmer, or lighter. Really notice how the sensations of tension are different from the sensations of relaxation you are now experiencing.
With each breath, allow more tension to drain from your calves, relaxing more and more deeply.
Continue to breathe slowly, thinking the word \"Relax\" each time you exhale, continuing to let any remaining tension drain away, breathing in, and out, in, and out.
Relax, relax.

Now that your whole body is feeling relaxed and comfortable, feel that sense of warmth and calmness spread over your whole body, continuing to breathe naturally, smoothly and steadily, letting the breath in and out, slowly and regularly, thinking the word \"relax\", every time you breathe out, breathing in, and out, in, and out.
As you continue to breathe, imagine a wave of relaxation slowly spreading throughout your body.
Starting at your head and gradually penetrating all of your muscles, all of the cells in your body, all the way down to your toes.

Allow yourself to relax completely, continuing to breathe slowly and smoothly, sinking into that feeling of relaxation and noticing how it feels, so that you will be able to access it and recreate it later on your own.

In a moment, I\'m going to count from 5 to 1. As I do, you will gradually feel more and more alert. When I get to 3, open your eyes, and when I get to 1, you will feel alert and refreshed and ready for the rest of your day.
5, 4, beginning to shift your body, feeling a bit more awake now, 3, opening your eyes, 2, a bit more awake now, 1.
Now you are feeling refreshed and alert, relaxed and ready for whatever is next.

Restricting the time you spend in bed can actually help you sleep better. If you have discussed specific times with your provider or would like to select your own bed times and wake times, choose \“Manually\” to enter the times that work best for you. If you would like the app to generate ideal bed times and wake times weekly, based on data from your sleep log, choose \“Automatically\”, then select the day you would like it to update each week. In order to calculate a sleep prescription the program needs data from your sleep diary for at least five nights in the past week.\n\nRemember, safety should always be considered when deciding how much time to allow for sleep. It is recommended you work with a provider to determine your best sleep prescription. If you have sleep apnea or if you find yourself very sleep during the day, visit the \"I Need Sleep\" section to take the questionnaire before determining a sleep prescription. Never restrict your sleep to the point where it affects your daily functioning.

One part of CBT-i is using a \“sleep prescription\”, which gives people set times to get into bed and get out of bed. This has been shown to help people get deeper, more satisfying sleep.

This may be uncomfortable at first, however, because you may notice that you are spending less time in bed than you are used to. This questionnaire assesses your sleep need, to see if your sleep prescription should be changed.

Always check in with your provider about making changes to your sleep schedule. Make sure to be careful about how much you restrict your sleep. Operating on not enough sleep can be dangerous - safety should always come first when trying to change your sleeping habits.

This assessment is called the sleep need questionnaire. This quiz can give you some valuable information about whether you and your provider should consider increasing your time in Bed. However, remember to speak to a provider if you find yourself becoming very sleepy. \n\nSince this quiz is designed to show your change over time related to your sleeping habits it is recommended that you take it no more than once a week

This self-assessment, the Insomnia Severity Index, cannot tell you if you have insomnia, but can give you some valuable information about your sleep symptoms. If you are currently working with a sleep therapist, sharing the results of this assessment with him or her may help with your care.

It has been less than a week since you last took the self-assessment. The questions are designed to assess your symptoms since the last time you answered, so it is generally not helpful to take it more than once a week.

Your score suggests that you do not have symptoms meeting criteria for insomnia at this time. \n\nHowever, if you are feeling stressed, make an appointment with a healthcare professional. A professional will be able to help you understand what is going on and provide ways to deal with stress.

You are reporting a number of sleep problems, similar to people who have been diagnosed with insomnia. If you continue to have these kinds of sleep problems over the next several weeks, you should talk with a trained health care provider. Seeking help will be especially important if you think that you may have other problems which can interfere with sleep, such as depression, substance abuse, PTSD or anxiety. This app can help you learn effective strategies for improving your sleep and allows you to keep track of how well you’re sleeping over time. Take this assessment again in four weeks so you can keep an eye on your symptoms.

Your score is still within the normal range.

However, this assessment will not pick up other problems that can be related to life stress such as depression, substance abuse, and anxiety.

If you are feeling stressed make an appointment with a healthcare professional, regardless of the outcome of this assessment. A professional will be able to help you understand what is going on and provide ways to deal with stress.

The sleep problems that you are reporting do not suggest insomnia. Your score is an improvement over your previous scores on this assessment. Answer the sleep questions again in four weeks so you can keep an eye on your symptoms. If you continue to use this app to support good sleep habits, you may find that you will continue to sleep well. However, don’t be alarmed if minor sleep difficulties occur once in a while. It’s not unusual to have occasional sleep problems, especially during times of increased stress. If you are feeling very stressed make an appointment with a healthcare professional, regardless of the outcome of this assessment. A professional will be able to help you understand what is going on and what you can do to deal with stress.

You are continuing to report a number of sleep problems, similar to people who have been diagnosed with insomnia. Share the results of this assessment with your health care provider. Take this assessment again in four weeks so you can keep an eye on your symptoms and try to include the information and tools in this app in your bedtime routine.

You are reporting a number of sleep problems which are similar to people who have been diagnosed with insomnia. Your sleep may have gotten worse since you last took the assessment.
